bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Ronald Ross, August 9, 1906

div1.p: Gorgas suggests that Finlay and Carter be nominated for the Nobel Prize. In the postscript, Gorgas writes an autograph note for Carter.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Ronald Ross, August 9, 1906
div1.opener:
C O P Y .
August 9, 1906.
Dr. Ronald Ross,
Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine,
Liverpool, England.
Dear Doctor Ross:
div1.p:
You recollect that when you were here you spoke to me about cer-
tain letters which I was to write you, concerning Dr. Finley and Dr. Carter, and
their relation to the discovery of the part the mosquito plays in yellow fever.
You thought at the time that you would propose them for the Nobel Prize. I
merely mention it to remind you. It seems to me that the prize might very
well be given to America in this connection. It would somewhat balance the
fact that it had been given to Sanarelli for his work which has turned out since
to have so little foundation in fact.

This work, it seems to me, is way and beyond in importance many of
the subjects that have received prizes in the last few years. In fact the
only original research work whose practical results at all compare with it, is
your work with regard to the mosquito and malaria.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, Dear Carter
I send you this extract in order that you may be braced
up in case those old Norwegians should show any
sense. I'll let you know what your friends think of you
W. C. Gorgas
